headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Before we get s
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to know that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2010 Form 10-K, fiscal 2011 Form 10-Qs and fiscal 2011 and 2012 form 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Ch
componenttext:
Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director, Investor Relations. We'll begin with a review of our fourth quarter and 2011 performance, followed by our outlook for 2012. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
We are very pleased with our robust sales and earnings in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011, especially considering they were achieved on top of strong multiyear gains. Our healthy revenue growth continues to be driven mainly by our ability to deliver compelling bargains on a wide assortment of exciting name-brand fashions for the family and the home to today's increasingly value-focused consumers. In addition, we continue to operate our business on lower in-store inventories, which benefited profit margins by driving faster trends and lower markdowns. It also enhanced sales by increasing the percentage of fresh merchandise in our stores. 
Earnings per share for the 13 weeks ended January 28, 2012, were $0.85, up from $0.69 for the 13 weeks ended January 29, 2011. These results represent a 23% increase on top of 18% and 53% gains in the fourth quarters of 2010 and 2009, respectively. Net earnings for the 2011 fourth quarter grew 19% to $192 million. For the 52 weeks ended January 28, 2012, earnings per share were $2.86, up 24% on top of 31% and 52% gains in fiscal 2010 and 2009. Net earnings for fiscal 2011 increased 18% to $657.2 million. 
Fourth quarter sales rose 12% to $2,398,000,000, with comparable store sales up 7% on top of 4% and 10% gains in the fourth quarter of the prior 2 years. For the full year, total sales grew 9% to $8,608,000,000, with same-store sales up 5% on top of 5% and 6% increases in 2010 and 2009, respectively. 
Juniors and Shoes were the best performing merchandise categories for the quarter. For the full year, the strongest businesses were Dresses, Shoes and Juniors. Geographic trends were broad-based with all regions boasting solid same-store sales increases for both the quarter and the year. Florida was the top region for both periods. 
Earnings before interest and taxes for the 2011 fourth quarter grew to 13% of sales, up about 70 basis points on top of 60 and 260 basis point increases in the prior 2 years. For fiscal 2011, operating margin rose to a record 12.4%, up 85 basis points on top of 140 and 250 basis point gains in fiscal 2010 and 2009, respectively. Our improved profit margins for both the quarter and the full year were driven primarily by a combination of higher merchandise gross margin, lower shortage costs and leverage on operating expenses from the strong gain in same-store sales. John will provide some additional color on these operating margin trends in a few minutes. 
As we ended the fourth quarter, total consolidated inventories were up about 4% compared to the prior year mainly due to higher packaway levels that were about 49% of total inventories, up from 47% at this time last year. In-store inventories were down on an average about 7% in 2011 on top of double-digit declines in the prior 3 years. Our expansion plans remained on track as we added 49 net new Ross Stores during the quarter. 
As previously mentioned on our November earnings call, this growth included our initial entry into the Midwest region in October, with the opening of 12 new Ross Dress for Less stores in the greater Chicago area. As planned, we also accelerated new store growth at dd's DISCOUNTS in 2011, adding 21 locations and ending the year with 88 stores in 7 states. This business continued to deliver solid sales in 2011 and had significant gains in operating profit compared to 2010 when it realized its first year of positive earnings. Similar to Ross, dd's has benefited from our ability to deliver a faster flow of fresh and exciting product to our stores while operating on lower inventory levels. 
Now let's talk about our financial condition. Operating cash flows provided the resources to make capital investments in new store growth and infrastructure, as well as fund our ongoing stock repurchase and dividend programs. In November, we announced the 2-for-1 stock split, and more recently, in January 2012, our board of directors raised the quarterly cash dividend 27% to $0.14 per share. This represented the 18th consecutive annual dividend increase since the program was initiated in 1994. Our recent stock split and ongoing stock repurchase and dividend programs reflect our commitment to enhance stockholder returns. They also demonstrate confidence in our continued ability to achieve our growth targets while generating significant amounts of excess cash after self-funding the capital needs of our business. 
Now John will provide further color on our fourth quarter results and details on our first quarter and fiscal year 2012 guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 7% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by a
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 7% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by about 70 basis points in the quarter to 13%. Cost of goods sold improved by 5 basis points, benefiting from a 35 basis point increase in merchandise margin, including 15 basis points of lower shrink expense. Other positive drivers included 35 basis points in lower distribution costs and 30 basis points of leverage on occupancy these favorable trends were partially offset by 50 basis points in higher buying costs, mainly due to the timing of incentive expenses versus last year and 45 basis points of increased shrink expense primarily from higher rates and fuel costs versus last year. 
Leverage on the strong 7% comparable store sales gain in the quarter drove a 65 basis point reduction in selling, general and administrative costs. Store operating expenses declined by about 40 basis points, while G&A costs were 25 basis points lower. As Michael mentioned, for fiscal 2011, operating margin rose to a record 12.4%, up 85 basis points over the prior year. Total cost of goods sold improved by 35 basis points, mainly due to a 50 basis point gain in merchandise gross margin, which included a 15 basis point benefit from lower shrink and 20 basis points of occupancy leverage. These favorable gains were partially offset by slight increases in freight, distribution and buying expenses of 2010 and 5 basis points, respectively. 
Selling, general and administrative costs for the year improved by 50 basis points as the 5% increase in comparable store sales levered for store and G&A expenses. 
Turning to our stock buyback program, during the fourth quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares for a total purchase price of $107 million. For the 2011 fiscal year, we repurchased 11.3 million shares for a total price of $450 million, representing half of our 2-year $900 million authorization. We expect to complete as planned the remaining $450 million in fiscal year 2012. 
We opened 70 net new stores in fiscal 2011, ending the year with 1,037 Ross Dress for Less stores in 29 states and, as Michael mentioned, 88 dd's DISCOUNTS in 7 states. 
Now I'll spend a few moments summarizing the underlying assumptions that support our 2012 EPS targets. A more detailed version is available in the written transcript of our January sales release recorded comments in the Investors section of our corporate website. 
Our fiscal year 2012 earnings per share forecast of $3.12 to $3.27 was based on projected sales growth of 7% to 8% for the 53 weeks ending February 2, 2013, compared to the 52 weeks ended January 28, 2012. This top line growth is forecast to be mainly driven by a 6% to 7% increase in the net number of stores and 1% to 2% growth in same-store sales. Our forecasted store growth for 2012 includes about 60 new or relocated Ross Dress for Less and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS locations. About 1/3 of these stores are targeted to open in new markets. These openings do not reflect our plans to close or relocate about 10 older stores. 
Our fiscal 2012 EBIT target is 12.5% to 12.7%, including an approximate 20 basis point benefit from the 53rd week. This suggests that operating margin on a 52-week basis will be relatively flat to 2012 compared to 2011. A modest increase in merchandise gross margin, driven by a mid single-digit decline in selling store inventory throughout the year, is expected to be offset by some slight deleveraging of buying and occupancy costs from the forecasted 1% to 2% gain in same-store sales. We also expect somewhat lower selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales mainly due to a projected decline in incentive costs compared to last year. Net interest expense is expected to be about $8 million. Our tax rate is planned to be approximately 38% and we extract approximate 3% to 4% decline in average diluted shares outstanding to about 223 million. 
Our first quarter guidance that we issued at the beginning of February was for same-store sales to be up 1% to 2%. We also projected earnings per share to be in the range of $0.82 to $0.86, up 11% to 16% from $0.74 in the fiscal quarter of 2011. Earlier this month, we reported a much better-than-expected same-store sales gain of 9% for February. That was aided by favorable weather throughout most of our markets, and with most of the quarter ahead of us, we reiterated our forecast for same-store sales to be up 1% to 2% in both March and April. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Michael for some closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Again, we are pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011. Despite exceedingly tough multiyear comparisons for both periods, we were able to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings. We continue to benefit
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Again, we are pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011. Despite exceedingly tough multiyear comparisons for both periods, we were able to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings. We continue to benefit from an increased focus on value by consumers, combined with a diligent execution of a number of strategies we have implemented throughout the company. Our top priority, of course, is continuing to strengthen our ability to acquire terrific name-brand bargains for our stores. To achieve this, we are making further investments in our merchandise organization. This is the key to both maximizing our access to the best opportunities for products and further expanding our very large vendor base. 
We also believe there is still room for additional reductions in selling store inventories. Today, these levels are almost 40% lower than just 4 years ago and we are targeting an additional mid-single-digit percentage decrease for 2012. Operating with less product in our stores had benefited merchandise margins due to fewer markdowns. Charting our merchandise faster has also enhanced sales by increasing the percentage of fresh merchandise in front of our customers. Our planning and allocation systems and processes have been rolled out for 2 full years now. They are helping us do a better job of getting the right merchandise to the right store at the right time. Planning and allocating at a much more detailed level is more important than ever today, especially with less inventory in our stores. Our performance has also benefited from our shortage control program which has resulted today in record low levels of shrink. In addition, we have implemented numerous productivity enhancements and efficiencies throughout the business to drive down costs in our distribution centers, stores organization and back-office functions. All of this gives us the confidence to continue to target over the longer term average annual earnings per share growth of 10% to 15%. The formula for achieving this is a combination of unit growth, annual increases in same-store sales and reduction in shares from our ongoing stock repurchase programs. 
At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you might have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for you. First of all, you had a very sharp jump in capital spending this past year and I'm wondering if you can just talk about plans for CapEx for the next couple of years. And then I do have 1 follow-up question.
componenttext: A couple of questions for you. First of all, you had a very sharp jump in capital spending this past year and I'm wondering if you can just talk about plans for CapEx for the next couple of years. And then I do have 1 follow-up question.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So, Jeff, you're right. As far as CapEx is concerned, we did increase that spending in 2011 up from 2010, and our estimates for 2012 are around $450 million and there's a couple of drivers. One is, the types of stores we're building now tend to require mo
componenttext: So, Jeff, you're right. As far as CapEx is concerned, we did increase that spending in 2011 up from 2010, and our estimates for 2012 are around $450 million and there's a couple of drivers. One is, the types of stores we're building now tend to require more capital because we are taking up a possession of the buildout of those stores as the capital markets have pretty much put a crimp on development of shopping centers. The second piece is, in the distribution area, we are beginning to plan the buildout of the company new distribution centers in the future years. So that is taking a bit more CapEx as we get those activities ramped up and going. And also, in the fourth quarter of this year, we've purchased corporate headquarters and we purchased some other stores, so that added to some CapEx as well.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, are you actually taking ownership of the stores?
componenttext: Okay, are you actually taking ownership of the stores?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't. At 1 store, we had a pretty significant opportunity where we actually did buy the store, but that's really the exception to what we do. We only own a couple of the 1,000 or more stores that we operate.
componenttext: We don't. At 1 store, we had a pretty significant opportunity where we actually did buy the store, but that's really the exception to what we do. We only own a couple of the 1,000 or more stores that we operate.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just a question for Mike. Wondering if e-commerce is in your future.
componenttext: Got it. And just a question for Mike. Wondering if e-commerce is in your future.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Actually I'll take that, Jeff. It's Mike O'Sullivan. E-commerce is an area that we've looked at very closely. Our assessment is that currently, it's very hard for an off-price business to make money in e-commerce, especially at the price points that we op
componenttext: Actually I'll take that, Jeff. It's Mike O'Sullivan. E-commerce is an area that we've looked at very closely. Our assessment is that currently, it's very hard for an off-price business to make money in e-commerce, especially at the price points that we operate at. But it's something that we're going to the team to look at. And if our model starts to emerge online, where we think that might change and where we think we can make money, it's certainly something we'll take a closer look at. I would say, though, that our policy right now rather than online is actually were off-line and bricks and mortar business where we know the returns are very strong and we have attractive growth opportunities. That's really a focus for us, off-line rather than online.

componenttext: I'll address the latter part of that question first, Tracy. Our packaway levels, we had planned the neighborhood where we are currently. We don't see that movement up or down. Having said that, as we know from our past, that has margins become available, we want to take advantage of those margins, so there tends to be some variation to put those plans might be, whether those buys, we're eternally optimistic. As what was the first part of your question related to merchandise margin?

componenttext: Yes from a merchandise margin standpoint, the plan for 2012 really contemplates us managing inventories tighter. We think we can manage inventories down in the mid-single-digit level which should deliver out better market performance, so that's we're anticipating for 2012.

componenttext: I'll answer that. It's Mike O'Sullivan again. It's very early in new markets. We've only been -- those stores have only been opened around 5 months. So in terms of your specific question on any unusual trends around circuits or track traffic, nothing to call out, no. There's nothing out of line in terms of what we see in the new markets for us as the rest of the chain. What I would say is everyday we've seen so far in terms sales performance, customer research and just customer feedback, sort of reinforces our belief that we're going to be successful in those markets long term.

componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of that in terms of performance. Dd's, as Michael mentioned in his remarks, dd's had a very solid sales performance in 2011, beating our internal plans, more notably had a very strong profit performance last year and that profit p
componenttext: I'll take the first part of that in terms of performance. Dd's, as Michael mentioned in his remarks, dd's had a very solid sales performance in 2011, beating our internal plans, more notably had a very strong profit performance last year and that profit performance was driven primarily by margins, which, in turn, were driven by lower inventories and sort of supply into the store. Similar strategy to what we've used at Ross over the last 3 years. So we've been very happy with dd's performance. I don't expect -- segueing into the next part of your question, I don't expect any major straight changes to strategy in dd's. We're pretty happy with the strategic direction of that business. Obviously, we'll make adjustments to improvements to get the assortment or to operations as we identify our improvement. But no major changes. We're pretty happy with the direction.

componenttext: In general, we don't comment on other retailers business models or strategies. But we overlap with Penney's customers, I would say we do. I don't have a number off the top of my mind right now. But certainly, any dislocations in supply that create some uncertainties in this whole supply line usually are a good thing for Ross. That's how I look at the JCPenney situation. It's really kind of a watch-and-see, and virtually every department store customer or most department store customers, there are some overlaps with our pricing.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So as to shortage, Brian, we take our fiscal inventory in the third quarter and then we'll adjust whatever our accrual rate was during the third quarter. For the first couple of quarters of this year, we expect about a 10 basis point improvement. That's j
componenttext: So as to shortage, Brian, we take our fiscal inventory in the third quarter and then we'll adjust whatever our accrual rate was during the third quarter. For the first couple of quarters of this year, we expect about a 10 basis point improvement. That's just based on what we will accrue in the third accrual to take inventory. For the plan for the year, because we have record low levels of shortage, we're not anticipating any benefit to be derived out of shortage this year. For the past several years, we have had very, very good outstanding results, so that's not delve into anything this year because of where we currently are.

componenttext: Okay, Kimberly, you're right. Actually, dd's became profitable in 2010 and it's a possibility to further in 2011, so we're very happy with its profit performance in 2011. In terms of our store potential, we believe this concept of growth of about 500 stores. And in terms of four-wall profitability, you're right. As we've commented in the past, if you look on a four-wall basis, and by that, I mean if you take gross margin and subtract all store-related expenses, dd's is comfortably profitable to a Ross Store. So that actually gives us encouragement as dd's build scale over time. This is going to be an exciting business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: My question is, as we're starting to see some signs of the economies improving, when you look back historically, that doesn't necessarily help off price in terms of your performance or at least relative performance. Can you just talk about your and after
componenttext: My question is, as we're starting to see some signs of the economies improving, when you look back historically, that doesn't necessarily help off price in terms of your performance or at least relative performance. Can you just talk about your and after last year and the last couple of years where you've been outperforming the apparel industry, what might be different this time as the economy recovers that might not hurt you?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're right. First of all, we believe off price, particularly in our model, oil price has executed well and does well in good times and bad times. I think that is, it's been a while since environments become less promotional. Off price, specifically, Ros
componenttext: You're right. First of all, we believe off price, particularly in our model, oil price has executed well and does well in good times and bad times. I think that is, it's been a while since environments become less promotional. Off price, specifically, Ross, we do better when we're in a not promotional environment or a less promotional environment. So I think that would be healthy for our business, and certainly, if I coupled the dislocation of supply that could be going on now based on changes in strategies, that will help fuel our supply line during this period. And finally, I think our packaway position puts us in a much better position, in a very strong position to do well and if the economy starts to move a little up-tempo. So less commercial environment in a better economy, we think will be good for us. And 1 other big difference from the last time that we've been in the good economic situation, a lot of retailers have gone away, so I think we find ourselves in a better position just by surviving and being reasonably a profitable retail this time.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Collins Stewart.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: John, my question's for you. I mean Ross has done a great job of exceeding its same-store sales guidance on a pretty consistent basis and it still looks like the outlook is conservative. Can you give us some insight in how you formulate your same-store sa
componenttext: John, my question's for you. I mean Ross has done a great job of exceeding its same-store sales guidance on a pretty consistent basis and it still looks like the outlook is conservative. Can you give us some insight in how you formulate your same-store sales outlook?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we look at the year, single year or multiple years, our objective is to grow earnings 10% to 15%. From that, we'll basically go bottoms up. We'll figure out the stores growth needed to arrive at that. We also figure out that the comp level seem
componenttext: Sure. When we look at the year, single year or multiple years, our objective is to grow earnings 10% to 15%. From that, we'll basically go bottoms up. We'll figure out the stores growth needed to arrive at that. We also figure out that the comp level seems reasonable. Keep in mind that this year, we're up against 3 pretty spectacular years of '05 and '06 and so we're up against some pretty rough numbers. Our business, if we can make the P&L work, you see that 10% to 15% earnings potential on a pretty reasonable comp,  good things happen if we see that comp. So we do tend to plan the business with conservative bias and we'll always have to do better.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And John, did you take into account when you said that comp guidance, what changes are taking place in the competitive environment?
componenttext: And John, did you take into account when you said that comp guidance, what changes are taking place in the competitive environment?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, we take all of that into consideration.
componenttext: Sure, we take all of that into consideration.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I just wanted some more color on the new markets. The 20 new stores in new markets , would that be in addition to the Chicago metro region? Or is there another region you're going to enter? And if you could also comment on Chicago's contribution as si
componenttext: And I just wanted some more color on the new markets. The 20 new stores in new markets , would that be in addition to the Chicago metro region? Or is there another region you're going to enter? And if you could also comment on Chicago's contribution as simplistic as you can. I know you're not going to provide earnings by store, but some sense as to traffic or volume compared to new stores in existing markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So yes, as Michael commented, about 1/3 of the new stores this year will be in new markets. And Chicago is, by far, the biggest of those new markets. There are a few other smaller markets in the Midwest region that will account for the rest of those 20 ne
componenttext: So yes, as Michael commented, about 1/3 of the new stores this year will be in new markets. And Chicago is, by far, the biggest of those new markets. There are a few other smaller markets in the Midwest region that will account for the rest of those 20 new stores. In terms of how the Chicago stores are performing, again, too early, 5 months in. Here, I think we're very quite happy with what we've seen, but I wouldn't expect like from at this point it's just too early. But as a general point, everything we've seen and heard in terms of research we've conducted, customer feedback we've gotten, as well as the early performance continues to reinforce our belief that we're going to be successful in this market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Should we see the continued growth in new markets as a sign of success for the micro-merchandising initiatives that began several years ago?
componenttext: Should we see the continued growth in new markets as a sign of success for the micro-merchandising initiatives that began several years ago?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: To some degree, it's not the only thing that we've done, so I think there are a number of components that sort of made us comfortable expanding to you markets last year and give us encouragement as we continue to expand. I think micro-merchandising is 1 p
componenttext: To some degree, it's not the only thing that we've done, so I think there are a number of components that sort of made us comfortable expanding to you markets last year and give us encouragement as we continue to expand. I think micro-merchandising is 1 piece, which really is a way of sort of adapting our assortments at a local level and trending those assortments more rapidly than we would've been able to before. So I think it's a very important tool in new markets.  But I think some of the other investments we've made, I think the investments we've made in the merch include in the last 5 years or so, which is basically the whole chain should also benefit new markets and close the merchandise and assortments have gone up. And I think the other aspect is the fact that we're carrying less inventory per store, which means that we're able to react much more quickly to trends that we see in an individual market. So I think this package of things we've done over the last 2 years which give us encouragement that we can be successful in the new markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: You've been pretty quiet about the Home business and I was just curious if we can get a little bit of an update on the Home business in Ross Stores and then how, if it's often successful at dd's, do you guys packaway product in this space at all? I'm just curious.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Home business in both concepts we're very pleased with, just not in the top 2 performers of the company, in both companies, and we are very pleased with where robbers we've made. I would say we pack away some product but nothing relative to the margins we
componenttext: Home business in both concepts we're very pleased with, just not in the top 2 performers of the company, in both companies, and we are very pleased with where robbers we've made. I would say we pack away some product but nothing relative to the margins we do in non-Home business. But we used effectively.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is it a similar business at dd's as it is in Ross?
componenttext: Is it a similar business at dd's as it is in Ross?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a little different, okay. It's a little less gifts-driven, little more utilitarian driven.
componenttext: It's a little different, okay. It's a little less gifts-driven, little more utilitarian driven.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: In Q4 thus far, we've seen much better inventory controls from apparel and retailers so far. What are you seeing in terms of inventory availability?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Actually, we're seeing quite store availability. What exactly industry that is, I know what I've been reading. I've been reading the same things you have, but there's been plenty of inventory in a fairly broad-based way.
componenttext: Actually, we're seeing quite store availability. What exactly industry that is, I know what I've been reading. I've been reading the same things you have, but there's been plenty of inventory in a fairly broad-based way.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One with respect to the inventory reductions that you've executed in the stores, the significant reductions over the last few years, I'm just curious if you're now recognizing any opportunities or needs to reconsider stor
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One with respect to the inventory reductions that you've executed in the stores, the significant reductions over the last few years, I'm just curious if you're now recognizing any opportunities or needs to reconsider store format, store fixturing, any thoughts for kind of a net reduction in-store prototype as you open new stores? And then 1 other thing, John, you commented on kind of a lack of shopping center development and how that's playing into your cost of real estate. And I was curious if you can elaborate on that a little bit more? What are you seeing in the commercial development side and what's happening net-net to your real estate costs?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll take the question on the impact of inventories or less inventories in our stores. So we design our stores with flexible fixtures, and flexibility enables us to expand and contract at any given category within a store. But as we brought down our inven
componenttext: I'll take the question on the impact of inventories or less inventories in our stores. So we design our stores with flexible fixtures, and flexibility enables us to expand and contract at any given category within a store. But as we brought down our inventories, we have flexible model as well that enables us to open up smaller stores where needed. So based on the demographic information that we use, we'll either open up a smaller-sized store to fit that need or a larger store. So the model overall is very flexible on it, and it's worked well for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: But in general, we have not a dramatically, we have shrunk our prototype over the last couple of years, knowing where we're going with our inventory.
componenttext: But in general, we have not a dramatically, we have shrunk our prototype over the last couple of years, knowing where we're going with our inventory.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jeff, on the second part of your question, when we take ownership and build out a store, the CapEx in that store is probably got $1.5 million. It's a landlord account that our fixture and et cetera cost about $0.5 million. That $1 million you negotiate, o
componenttext: Jeff, on the second part of your question, when we take ownership and build out a store, the CapEx in that store is probably got $1.5 million. It's a landlord account that our fixture and et cetera cost about $0.5 million. That $1 million you negotiate, obviously, you negotiate your rents down, so we pay back over a period of time. And so as we see the current markets get reestablished, development gets reestablished, we'd want to switch back to more of what we call a turnkey approach where the landlord is owning that these hold improvements will be our preference.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, just a quick follow-up on the store prototype, Michael, is there a target prototype size, average size going forward that would deviate to some percentage from prior trends?
componenttext: Okay, just a quick follow-up on the store prototype, Michael, is there a target prototype size, average size going forward that would deviate to some percentage from prior trends?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say that the prototype size is smaller than what we've opened in the past. But we've always had a flexible model that's enabled us to open buildings that are larger than prototype. But I say most of them today tend to trend more towards smaller th
componenttext: I would say that the prototype size is smaller than what we've opened in the past. But we've always had a flexible model that's enabled us to open buildings that are larger than prototype. But I say most of them today tend to trend more towards smaller than our average prototypes. So we're finding the ability to merchandise these better than we have in the past. It provides us with increased availability when we're flexible and we're able to get different sizes. But 1 of the benefits of having less inventory is we don't need this availability.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Montagna from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Montagna from Avondale Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just kind of following along with the questions that we were just talking about, have you thought about moving the backlog forward to make the store look forward? I guess there's a lot of stores where I've been in, shelves around and possibly trying to im
componenttext: Just kind of following along with the questions that we were just talking about, have you thought about moving the backlog forward to make the store look forward? I guess there's a lot of stores where I've been in, shelves around and possibly trying to improve the look of the store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we spend a lot of time and resources ensuring that the customer experience is right by location. And some of the examples that you've given, we've added walls to make sure that we have a customer-friendly environment. And as we evolve our fixtures
componenttext: I think we spend a lot of time and resources ensuring that the customer experience is right by location. And some of the examples that you've given, we've added walls to make sure that we have a customer-friendly environment. And as we evolve our fixtures and as we evolve our merchandising standards and skills, it's focused on ensuring that the store looks right and is presented in an appropriate way for our customer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would add that our customers seem to be responding favorably to having an environment that is easier to shop, and I understand that in some cases, we're showing a little more wall or a lot more wall, a lot more chrome. And the customers seem to be doing
componenttext: I would add that our customers seem to be responding favorably to having an environment that is easier to shop, and I understand that in some cases, we're showing a little more wall or a lot more wall, a lot more chrome. And the customers seem to be doing favorably. That was not a big issue for them as they're finding the right bargains.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just kind of along those lines, in terms of your in-store inventories, can you talk about how fast your inventory is turning now versus how fast it was turning before you got on this inventory reduction initiative?
componenttext: Okay. And then just kind of along those lines, in terms of your in-store inventories, can you talk about how fast your inventory is turning now versus how fast it was turning before you got on this inventory reduction initiative?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Mark. We're not the exact turn number. Clearly, inventories are down 40%. Sales were up so it's turning significantly faster.
componenttext: Yes, sure, Mark. We're not the exact turn number. Clearly, inventories are down 40%. Sales were up so it's turning significantly faster.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, in terms of expense leverage, can you talk about what comp is needed this year to leverage SG&A expense and what comps would be needed for the buying and occupancy portion of gross margin?
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, in terms of expense leverage, can you talk about what comp is needed this year to leverage SG&A expense and what comps would be needed for the buying and occupancy portion of gross margin?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we mentioned in our prior comments, because we planned the year without an incentive, we're picking up some leverage this year on the 1 to 2 comp we're leveraging it  a bit. Having said that, in the more comparable year-over-year period, and will
componenttext: Yes, as we mentioned in our prior comments, because we planned the year without an incentive, we're picking up some leverage this year on the 1 to 2 comp we're leveraging it  a bit. Having said that, in the more comparable year-over-year period, and will be taken it into account to leverage expenses.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: A few questions. componenttext: So on our policies, we don't have to comment on those sales. So we'll be out with that 1st of April.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a question when you think about you're hitting record EBIT levels this year, and obviously, next year, it sounds like we're going to set a new record, how should we think about dd's is that obviously has swung into improving profitability a
componenttext: Okay. And then a question when you think about you're hitting record EBIT levels this year, and obviously, next year, it sounds like we're going to set a new record, how should we think about dd's is that obviously has swung into improving profitability and that becomes less of a drag, how should we think about as that grows and that drag moderates, what potential health that could be to EBIT margins over time?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Adrienne, I'll take that. It's Michael O'Sullivan. I mentioned in an earlier response to an earlier question on dd's, a pretty good four-wall contribution level which tells us that average scale's up, it will become more profitable as a business. So we th
componenttext: Adrienne, I'll take that. It's Michael O'Sullivan. I mentioned in an earlier response to an earlier question on dd's, a pretty good four-wall contribution level which tells us that average scale's up, it will become more profitable as a business. So we think the long-term prospects for dd's are pretty good. I mean, I would caution you that right now, although dd's is profitable, it's less 8% of our store so it's really not a material impact on our overall P&L, at least not for a few years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Any sense in terms of the differential, in terms of margin contribution dd's versus Ross?
componenttext: Okay. Any sense in terms of the differential, in terms of margin contribution dd's versus Ross?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: It so hard to answer because dd's has less than 100 stores. Ross has more than 1,000, and that scale matters a lot. So it's hard to compare the second quarter I think suffice it to say, obviously, we're very happy with Ross EBIT margin and our long-term m
componenttext: It so hard to answer because dd's has less than 100 stores. Ross has more than 1,000, and that scale matters a lot. So it's hard to compare the second quarter I think suffice it to say, obviously, we're very happy with Ross EBIT margin and our long-term models tell us that dd's sales up, dd's will have an attractive profit margin.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay great. And then my next question, you obviously have been capitalizing on whether it's the D story and the value focus out there. I'm just wondering maybe if you could contextualize and shed some light in terms of the opportunities on the vendor rela
componenttext: Okay great. And then my next question, you obviously have been capitalizing on whether it's the D story and the value focus out there. I'm just wondering maybe if you could contextualize and shed some light in terms of the opportunities on the vendor relationships, what categories you're opening up, and without naming names, but how you're seeing the share shuffles that's going on, what that's doing in terms of opening doors to new vendors?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, this shuffle -- there's a lot of shuffling going on in the midtier and I certainly couldn't comment on any vendors, okay but this kind of shuffling is usually good for us. We're constant, we're stable, we're focused, we have a large volume organizat
componenttext: Well, this shuffle -- there's a lot of shuffling going on in the midtier and I certainly couldn't comment on any vendors, okay but this kind of shuffling is usually good for us. We're constant, we're stable, we're focused, we have a large volume organization, seeing lots of vendors, so the shuffling you're talking about is usually a very good thing for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then perhaps any way to quantify in terms of how many vendors you've got direct relationships, last year how that's improved, year-over-year?
componenttext: And then perhaps any way to quantify in terms of how many vendors you've got direct relationships, last year how that's improved, year-over-year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don't think that's a number I would -- actually, I don't think it's a quantifiable number. You're asking where we've improved relationships. We've improved relationships with a lot of vendors and I'm sure there are vendors you could call to say we are s
componenttext: I don't think that's a number I would -- actually, I don't think it's a quantifiable number. You're asking where we've improved relationships. We've improved relationships with a lot of vendors and I'm sure there are vendors you could call to say we are slightly worse than we were last year as a vendor relationships. So I don't think it's quantifiable.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you talk little bit about the systems enhancements, the shrinkage reduction that's obviously led to margin improvement, what is next on the docket for systems or shrinkage that we should continue to see margin improvement? How do you think about it? A
componenttext: Can you talk little bit about the systems enhancements, the shrinkage reduction that's obviously led to margin improvement, what is next on the docket for systems or shrinkage that we should continue to see margin improvement? How do you think about it? And then also, as you think about the buyers, and we've always heard about adding to the buying team, where are you on the people side and what should be added, any new categories we should be watching for?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dana, let me take the first part of your question and split it into 2. I'll address the systems issue, and then separately, we'll talk about shrink. So on systems,  I guess, the way we think about it, there are 3 buckets to sort of systems investment, esp
componenttext: Dana, let me take the first part of your question and split it into 2. I'll address the systems issue, and then separately, we'll talk about shrink. So on systems,  I guess, the way we think about it, there are 3 buckets to sort of systems investment, especially sort of continually upgrading and improving our systems or improving things like information security and merchandise and operation reporting, a bunch of things that you'd actually do on a continual basis. Secondly, there's a systems investment that we make to sort of improve what I would call operational efficiency, within our stores or within our DCs. And then certainly, there's a bucket of strategic investments, things like micro-merchandising. And we continue to look for those kind of strategic investments ways that IT systems investments can help the overall business and we have some things in the pipeline, nothing on the scale of micro-merchandising at this point but things that we're looking at. So that's kind of how I would sum up the systems side of things.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll take the shortage question. As we said earlier, we're on our third consecutive year of record lows in shortage. With that said, we continue to make targeted strategic investments designed to control our current levels of shortage. But with that, we'r
componenttext: I'll take the shortage question. As we said earlier, we're on our third consecutive year of record lows in shortage. With that said, we continue to make targeted strategic investments designed to control our current levels of shortage. But with that, we're hopeful to do better.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: On the buying side, from '11, in '11 I think we grew our merchandise organization slightly up for 10% and I would think we'll be growing the organization about the same amount in fiscal '12. There are new categories that we are putting into our store, but
componenttext: On the buying side, from '11, in '11 I think we grew our merchandise organization slightly up for 10% and I would think we'll be growing the organization about the same amount in fiscal '12. There are new categories that we are putting into our store, but in this environment, I just wouldn't be comfortable discussing it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: For next question comes from the line of David Glick with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: For next question comes from the line of David Glick with Buckingham Research.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Last year, at this point, we were trying to speculate about the impact of higher input cost and the impact it may have on your business. I wondered if you could your share your thoughts as we look out to the potential benefit of lower sourcing costs in th
componenttext: Last year, at this point, we were trying to speculate about the impact of higher input cost and the impact it may have on your business. I wondered if you could your share your thoughts as we look out to the potential benefit of lower sourcing costs in the second half and what, if any, impact that could have on your profitability?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Certainly, what happened last year was something we ought to get used to and the customer had to get used to a bit. In some cases, they did; in some cases, they didn't. As you move towards fall, there are some reductions going on as cotton prices have com
componenttext: Certainly, what happened last year was something we ought to get used to and the customer had to get used to a bit. In some cases, they did; in some cases, they didn't. As you move towards fall, there are some reductions going on as cotton prices have come down significantly. And I think the potential benefit for an off-price retailer is as prices come down, I would expect that certain places in the market will invest more in product. If they do that and business is not strong, in mainstream, there'll be opportunities for us, and that's what I think actually the potential benefit for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your last question comes from the line of Patrick McKeever from MKM Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your last question comes from the line of Patrick McKeever from MKM Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just another question, I know this was already asked, but maybe I'll ask it in a different way. On the March, April same-store sales guidance, the up 1% to 2% in both months, I mean, you look back over the years and you typically do see a pretty major dif
componenttext: Just another question, I know this was already asked, but maybe I'll ask it in a different way. On the March, April same-store sales guidance, the up 1% to 2% in both months, I mean, you look back over the years and you typically do see a pretty major difference in your March same-store sales and your April same-store sales for like last year, March was down 1%, April was up 10%. The big sling is pretty clear over the years. So I'm just wondering why Easter this year is 2 weeks earlier. So I'm wondering why this year would look different, which wouldn't see some kind of fairly significant swing in those months?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Easter's moving a week or 2. It's 2 weeks. It's probably you had some minimal moves and move 2010 was more significant. So from our perspective, it's not going to be that significant in a month. Having said that, we again -- our policy is not to c
componenttext: I think Easter's moving a week or 2. It's 2 weeks. It's probably you had some minimal moves and move 2010 was more significant. So from our perspective, it's not going to be that significant in a month. Having said that, we again -- our policy is not to comment on sales, but we do want to make sure that we are prepared into the Easter season which I think we'll don fine. In Easter, obviously, this year is due in fiscal April.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Before we get
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2011 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management, followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2010 Form 10-K, fiscal 2011 Form 10-Qs and fiscal 2011 and 2012 form 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to you, Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Ch
componenttext:
Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director, Investor Relations. We'll begin with a review of our fourth quarter and 2011 performance, followed by our outlook for 2012. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
We are very pleased with our robust sales and earnings in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011, especially considering they were achieved on top of strong multi-year gains. Our healthy revenue growth continues to be driven mainly by our ability to deliver compelling bargains on a wide assortment of exciting name-brand fashions for the family and the home to today's increasingly value-focused consumers. In addition, we continue to operate our business on lower in-store inventories, which benefited profit margins by driving faster turns and lower markdowns. It also enhanced sales by increasing the percentage of fresh merchandise in our stores. 
Earnings per share for the 13 weeks ended January 28, 2012, were $0.85, up from $0.69 for the 13 weeks ended January 29, 2011. These results represent a 23% increase on top of 18% and 53% gains in the fourth quarters of 2010 and 2009, respectively. Net earnings for the 2011 fourth quarter grew 19% to $192 million. For the 52 weeks ended January 28, 2012, earnings per share were $2.86, up 24% on top of 31% and 52% gains in fiscal 2010 and 2009. Net earnings for fiscal 2011 increased 18% to $657.2 million. 
Fourth quarter sales rose 12% to $2,398,000,000, with comparable store sales up 7% on top of 4% and 10% gains in the fourth quarter of the prior 2 years. For the full year, total sales grew 9% to $8,608,000,000, with same-store sales up 5% on top of 5% and 6% increases in 2010 and 2009, respectively. 
Juniors and Shoes were the best-performing merchandise categories for the quarter. For the full year, strongest businesses were Dresses, Shoes and Juniors. 
Geographic trends were broad-based with all regions posting solid same-store sales increases for both the quarter and the year. Florida was the top region for both periods. 
Earnings before interest and taxes for the 2011 fourth quarter grew to 13% of sales, up about 70 basis points on top of 60 and 260 basis point increases in the prior 2 years. For fiscal 2011, operating margin rose to a record 12.4%, up 85 basis points on top of 140 and 250 basis point gains in fiscal 2010 and 2009, respectively. Our improved profit margins for both the quarter and the full year were driven primarily by a combination of higher merchandise gross margin, lower shortage costs and leverage on operating expenses from the strong gain in same-store sales. John will provide some additional color on these operating margin trends in a few minutes. 
As we ended the fourth quarter, total consolidated inventories were up about 4% compared to the prior year mainly due to higher packaway levels that were about 49% of total inventories, up from 47% at this time last year. In-store inventories were down, on an average, about 7% in 2011 on top of double-digit declines in the prior 3 years. 
Our expansion plans remained on track as we added 49 net new Ross Stores during the quarter. As previously mentioned on our November earnings call, this growth included our initial entry into the Midwest region in October, with the opening of 12 new Ross Dress for Less stores in the greater Chicago area. As planned, we also accelerated new store growth at dd's DISCOUNTS in 2011, adding 21 locations and ending the year with 88 stores in 7 states. This business continued to deliver solid sales in 2011 and had a significant -- and have significant gains in operating profit compared to 2010 when it realized its first year of positive earnings. Similar to Ross, dd's has benefited from our ability to deliver a faster flow of fresh and exciting product to our stores while operating on lower inventory levels. 
Now let's talk about our financial condition. Operating cash flows provided the resources to make capital investments in new store growth and infrastructure, as well as fund our ongoing stock repurchase and dividend programs. In November, we announced the 2-for-1 stock split, and more recently, in January 2012, our Board of Directors raised the quarterly cash dividend 27% to $0.14 per share. This represented the 18th consecutive annual dividend increase since the program was initiated in 1994. Our recent stock split and ongoing stock repurchase and dividend programs reflect our commitment to enhance some stockholder returns. They also demonstrate confidence in our continued ability to achieve our growth targets while generating significant amounts of excess cash after self-funding the capital needs of our business. 
Now John will provide further color on our fourth quarter results and details on our first quarter and fiscal year 2012 guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 7% comparable store sales gain in the fourth quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in a number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by ab
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 7% comparable store sales gain in the fourth quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in a number of transactions, combined with a low single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by about 70 basis points in the quarter to 13%. 
Cost of goods sold improved by 5 basis points, benefiting from a 35 basis point increase in merchandise margin, including 15 basis points of lower shrink expense. Other positive drivers included 35 basis points of lower distribution costs and 30 basis points of leverage on occupancy. These favorable trends were partially offset by 50 basis points in higher buying costs, mainly due to the timing of incentive expenses versus last year and 45 basis points of increased shrink expense primarily from higher rates and fuel costs versus last year. 
Leverage on the strong 7% comparable store sales gain in the quarter drove a 65 basis point reduction in selling, general and administrative costs. Store operating expenses declined by about 40 basis points, while G&A costs were 25 basis points lower. As Michael mentioned, for fiscal 2011, operating margin rose to a record 12.4%, up 85 basis points over the prior year. Total cost of goods sold improved by 35 basis points, mainly due to a 50 basis point gain in merchandise gross margin, which included a 15 basis point benefit from lower shrink and 20 basis points of occupancy leverage. These favorable gains were partially offset by slight increases in freight, distribution and buying expenses of 2010 and 5 basis points, respectively.  Selling, general and administrative costs for the year improved by 50 basis points as the 5% increase in comparable store sales levered both store and G&A expenses. 
Turning to our stock buyback program. During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 2.2 million shares for a total purchase price of $107 million. For the 2011 fiscal year, we repurchased 11.3 million shares for a total price of $450 million, representing half of our 2-year $900 million authorization. We expect to complete, as planned, the remaining $450 million in fiscal year 2012. We opened 70 net new stores in fiscal 2011, ending the year with 1,037 Ross Dress for Less stores in 29 states and, as Michael mentioned, 88 dd's DISCOUNTS in 7 states. 
Now I'll spend a few moments summarizing the underlying assumptions that support our 2012 EPS targets. A more detailed version is available in the written transcript of our January sales release recorded comments in the Investors section of our corporate website. 
Our fiscal year 2012 earnings per share forecast of $3.12 to $3.27 was based on projected sales growth of 7% to 8% for the 53 weeks ending February 2, 2013, compared to the 52 weeks ended January 28, 2012. This top line growth is forecast to be mainly driven by a 6% to 7% increase in the net number of stores and 1% to 2% growth in same-store sales. Our forecasted store growth for 2012 includes about 60 new or relocated Ross Dress for Less and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS locations. About 1/3 of these stores are targeted to open in new markets. These openings do not reflect our plans to close or relocate about 10 older stores. 
Our fiscal 2012 EBIT target is 12.5% to 12.7%, including an approximate 20 basis point benefit from the 53rd week. This suggests that operating margin on a 52-week basis will be relatively flat to 2012 compared to 2011. A modest increase in merchandise gross margin, driven by a mid-single-digit decline in selling store inventories throughout the year, is expected to be offset by some slight deleveraging of buying and occupancy costs from the forecasted 1% to 2% gain in same-store sales. We also expect somewhat lower selling, general and administrative costs as a percent of sales mainly due to a projected decline in incentive costs compared to last year. Net interest expense is expected to be about $8 million. Our tax rate is planned to be approximately 38%, and we expect an approximate 3% to 4% decline in average diluted shares outstanding to about 223 million. 
Our first quarter guidance that we issued at the beginning of February was for same-store sales to be up 1% to 2%. We also projected earnings per share to be in the range of $0.82 to $0.86, up 11% to 16% from $0.74 in the fiscal quarter of 2011. Earlier this month, we reported a much better-than-expected same-store sales gain of 9% for February. That was aided by favorable weather throughout most of our markets. And with most of the quarter ahead of us, we reiterated our forecast for same-store sales to be up 1% to 2% in both March and April. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Michael for some closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Again, we are pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011. Despite exceedingly tough multi-year comparisons for both periods, we were able to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings. We continue to benefi
componenttext:
Thank you, John. Again, we are pleased with our performance in the fourth quarter and fiscal year of 2011. Despite exceedingly tough multi-year comparisons for both periods, we were able to achieve solid growth in sales and earnings. We continue to benefit from an increased focus on value by consumers, combined with a diligent execution of a number of strategies we have implemented throughout the company. Our top priority, of course, is continuing to strengthen our ability to acquire terrific name-brand bargains for our stores. To achieve this, we are making further investments in our merchandise organization. This is the key to both maximizing our access to the best opportunities for products and further expanding our very large vendor base. 
We also believe there is still room for additional reductions in selling store inventories. Today, these levels are almost 40% lower than just 4 years ago, and we are targeting an additional mid-single-digit percentage decrease for 2012. Operating with less product in our stores had benefited merchandise margins due to fewer markdowns. Turning our merchandise faster has also enhanced sales by increasing the percentage of fresh merchandise in front of our customers. 
Our planning and allocation systems and processes have been rolled out for 2 full years now. They are helping us do a better job of getting the right merchandise to the right store at the right time. Planning and allocating in a much more detailed level is more important than ever today, especially with less inventory in our stores. 
Our performance has also benefited from our shortage control program, which has resulted today in record low levels of shrink. In addition, we have implemented numerous productivity enhancements and efficiencies throughout the business to drive down costs in our distribution centers, stores organization and back-office functions. All of this gives us the confidence to continue to target over the longer term average annual earnings per share growth of 10% to 15%. The formula for achieving this is a combination of unit growth, annual increases in same-store sales and reductions in shares from our ongoing stock repurchase programs. 
At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you might have.

componenttext: A couple of questions for you. First of all, you had a very sharp jump in capital spending this past year, and I'm wondering if you can just talk about your plans for CapEx for the next couple of years? And then I do have one follow-up question.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So, Jeff, you're right. As far as CapEx is concerned, we did increase that spending in 2011, up from 2010. And our estimates for 2012 are around $450 million, and there's a couple of drivers. One is the types of stores we're building now tend to require m
componenttext: So, Jeff, you're right. As far as CapEx is concerned, we did increase that spending in 2011, up from 2010. And our estimates for 2012 are around $450 million, and there's a couple of drivers. One is the types of stores we're building now tend to require more capital because we are taking up a possession of the build-out of those stores as the capital markets have pretty much put a crimp on development of shopping centers. The second piece is, in the distribution area, we are beginning to plan the build-out of a couple of new distribution centers in the future years. So that is taking a bit more of CapEx as we get those activities ramped up and going. And also in the fourth quarter of this year, we've purchased corporate headquarters and we purchased another store, so that added to some CapEx as well. So I would expect...

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So are you actually taking ownership of the stores?
componenttext: Okay. So are you actually taking ownership of the stores?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't. On one store, we had a pretty significant opportunity where we actually did buy the store, but that's really the exception to what we do. We only own a couple of the 1,000 or more stores that we operate.
componenttext: We don't. On one store, we had a pretty significant opportunity where we actually did buy the store, but that's really the exception to what we do. We only own a couple of the 1,000 or more stores that we operate.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just a question for Mike. Wondering if e-commerce is in your future?
componenttext: Got it. And just a question for Mike. Wondering if e-commerce is in your future?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Actually, I'll take that, Jeff. It's Michael O'Sullivan. E-commerce is an area that we've certainly looked at very closely. Our assessment is that currently, it's very hard for an off-price business to make money in e-commerce, especially at the price poi
componenttext: Actually, I'll take that, Jeff. It's Michael O'Sullivan. E-commerce is an area that we've certainly looked at very closely. Our assessment is that currently, it's very hard for an off-price business to make money in e-commerce, especially at the price points that we operate at. But it's something that we're going to continue to look at. And if our model starts to emerge online, where we think that might change and where we think we can make money, it's certainly something we'll take a closer look at. I would say, though, that our priority right now is rather than online is actually our off-line, sort of bricks-and-mortar business where we know the returns are very strong and we have attractive growth opportunities. So that's really the focus for us, off-line rather than online.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: So I'll address that latter part of that question first, Tracy. Our packaway levels, we have planned kind of in the neighborhood of where we are currently. We don't see that movement up or down. Having said that, as we know from our past, that as bargains become available, we want to take advantage of those bargains, so there tends to be some variation to whatever those plans might be, if they -- those buys are totally opportunistic. componenttext: Yes. So from a merchandising margin standpoint, the plan for 2012 really contemplates us managing inventories tighter. We think we can manage inventories down into mid-single-digit level, which should deliver out better markdown performance. So that's what we're anticipating in 2012.

componenttext: Okay, I'll try to answer that. It's Michael O'Sullivan again. Yes, it's very early in the new markets. We've only been -- those stores have only been opened around 5 months. So in terms of your specific question on any unusual trends around tickets or traffic, nothing to call out, no. There's nothing out of line in terms of what we're seeing in the new markets versus the rest of the chain. What I would say is everything we've seen so far in terms sales performance, customer research and just customer feedback, sort of reinforces our belief that we're going to be successful in those markets long term.

componenttext: Okay. I'll take the first part of that in terms of performance. And that profit performance was driven primarily by margins, which, in turn, were driven by lower inventories and our sort of fresher supply of goods to the store, similar strategy to what we've used at Ross over the last few years. So we've been very happy with dd's performance. I don't expect -- segueing into the next part of your question, I don't expect any major changes to strategy at dd's. We're pretty happy with the strategic direction of that business. We'll make -- obviously, we'll make adjustments and improvements to the assortment or to operations as we identify areas for improvement. But no major changes. We're pretty happy with the direction.

componenttext: So as to shortage, Brian, we take our fiscal inventory in the third quarter, and then we'll adjust whatever our accrual rate was during the third quarter. For the first couple of quarters of this year, we expect about a 10 basis point improvement. That's just based on what we will accrue. And then the third quarter, we'll take inventory. For the plan for the year, because we have record low levels of that shortage, we're not anticipating any benefit to be derived out of shortage this year. While over the past several years, we have had very, very good outstanding shortage as a result. So that's not dialed into anything this year because of where we currently are.
