headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next question, from Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question, from Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand dd's. It reached profitability in 2011. Can you share with us your longer-term vision and what you view as store potential for that concept? And at a -- on a 4-wall basis, I think you had commented previously that dd's was just abou
componenttext: I wanted to understand dd's. It reached profitability in 2011. Can you share with us your longer-term vision and what you view as store potential for that concept? And at a -- on a 4-wall basis, I think you had commented previously that dd's was just about in line with Ross Stores or perhaps in line with Ross Stores. If you could just update us on the economics of dd's, that would be terrific. Lastly, 45 basis points of freight expense or I guess it was deleveraged in Q4. Can you just remind us when you start to anniversary those higher freight and fuel costs in your P&L in 2012?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Kimberly, you're right, dd's actually became profitable in 2010, and its profitability improved further in 2011. So we're very happy with its profit performance in 2011. In terms of our store potential, we believe that this concept can grow to about
componenttext: Okay. Kimberly, you're right, dd's actually became profitable in 2010, and its profitability improved further in 2011. So we're very happy with its profit performance in 2011. In terms of our store potential, we believe that this concept can grow to about 500 stores. And in terms of 4-wall profitability, you're right. As we've commented in the past, if you look on a 4-wall basis, and by that, I mean if you take gross margin and subtract all store-related expenses, dd's is comparably profitable to a Ross Store. So that actually gives us encouragement that as dd's build scale over time, this is going to be an attractive business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So, Kimberly, as to the freight question, a couple of drivers in that increase. Obviously, rate has something to do with that. We're looking at fuel pricing this year, which has to be determined on what costs will be. We have anticipating fuel going up to
componenttext: So, Kimberly, as to the freight question, a couple of drivers in that increase. Obviously, rate has something to do with that. We're looking at fuel pricing this year, which has to be determined on what costs will be. We have anticipating fuel going up to some extent but we'll have to see where it goes this year. So it's a bit of a headwind for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And store potential for dd's, we look at it. It's 500 stores at this point.
componenttext: And store potential for dd's, we look at it. It's 500 stores at this point.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: My question is as we're starting to see some signs of the economies improving, when you look back historically, that doesn't necessarily help off-price in terms of your performance or at least relative performance. Can you just talk about your -- after la
componenttext: My question is as we're starting to see some signs of the economies improving, when you look back historically, that doesn't necessarily help off-price in terms of your performance or at least relative performance. Can you just talk about your -- after last year and the last couple of years where you've been outperforming the apparel industry what might be different this time as the economy recovers that might not hurt you?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're right. First off, we believe off-price and specifically our model, off-prices executed well does well in good times and bad times. I think one thing that is -- it's been a while since environment’s become less promotional. Off-price, specifically
componenttext: You're right. First off, we believe off-price and specifically our model, off-prices executed well does well in good times and bad times. I think one thing that is -- it's been a while since environment’s become less promotional. Off-price, specifically Ross, we do better when we're in a non-promotional environment or less promotional environment. So I think that would be healthy for our business. And certainly, if I coupled out the dislocation of supply that could be going on now based on changes in strategies, that will help fuel our supply line during this period. And finally, I think our packaway position puts us in a much better position, in a very strong position to do well and if the economy starts to move a little up-tempo. So less commercial environments though in a better economy we think will be good for us. And one other big difference from the last time that we've been in the good economic situation, a lot of retailers have gone away. So I think we find ourselves in a better position just by surviving and being a reasonably profitable retailer in this time.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Collins Stewart.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Laura Champine from Collins Stewart.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: John, my question is for you. I mean, Ross has done a great job of exceeding its same-store sales guidance on a pretty consistent basis. And it still looks like the outlook is conservative. Can you give us some insight in how you formulate your same store
componenttext: John, my question is for you. I mean, Ross has done a great job of exceeding its same-store sales guidance on a pretty consistent basis. And it still looks like the outlook is conservative. Can you give us some insight in how you formulate your same store sales outlook?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we look at the year, single year and over multiple years, our objective is to grow earnings 10% to 15%. From that, we'll basically go bottoms up. We'll figure out the store growth needed to arrive at that. We'll also figure out the comp level t
componenttext: Sure. When we look at the year, single year and over multiple years, our objective is to grow earnings 10% to 15%. From that, we'll basically go bottoms up. We'll figure out the store growth needed to arrive at that. We'll also figure out the comp level that seems reasonable. Keep in mind that this year, we're up against 3 pretty spectacular years, a 5, a 5 and a 6. And so up against some pretty heavy numbers. In our business, it always -- if we can make the P&L work to achieve that 10% to 15% earnings potential on a pretty reasonable comp, good things happen if we exceed that comp. So we do tend to plan the business with a conservative bias, and we always hope to do better.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And John, are you taking into account when you said that comp guidance, what changes are taking place in the competitive environment?
componenttext: And John, are you taking into account when you said that comp guidance, what changes are taking place in the competitive environment?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, we take all that into consideration.
componenttext: Sure, we take all that into consideration.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Jaffe from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I just wanted some more color on the new markets. The 20 new stores in new markets, would that be in addition to the Chicago metro region, or is there another region you're going to enter? And if you could also comment on Chicago's contribution as sim
componenttext: And I just wanted some more color on the new markets. The 20 new stores in new markets, would that be in addition to the Chicago metro region, or is there another region you're going to enter? And if you could also comment on Chicago's contribution as simplistic as you can. I know you're not going to provide earnings by store, but some sense of traffic or volume compared to new stores in existing markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So yes, as Michael commented, about 1/3 of the new store this year will be in new markets. And Chicago is, by far, the biggest of those new markets. There are a few other smaller markets in the Midwest region that will account for the rest of those 20 new
componenttext: So yes, as Michael commented, about 1/3 of the new store this year will be in new markets. And Chicago is, by far, the biggest of those new markets. There are a few other smaller markets in the Midwest region that will account for the rest of those 20 new stores. In terms of how the Chicago stores are performing, again, it's too early, 5 months in. I think we're very, very happy with what we've seen, but I wouldn't extrapolate from it at this point. It's just too early. But as a general point, everything we've seen and heard in terms of research we've conducted, customer feedback we've gotten, as well as the early performance continues to reinforce our belief that we're going to be successful in this market.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Should we read the continued growth in new markets as a sign of success for the micro-merchandising initiatives that began several years ago?
componenttext: Should we read the continued growth in new markets as a sign of success for the micro-merchandising initiatives that began several years ago?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: To some degree, it's not the only thing that we've done. So I think there are a number of components that sort of made us comfortable expanding into new markets last year and give us encouragement as we continue to expand. I think micro-merchandising is o
componenttext: To some degree, it's not the only thing that we've done. So I think there are a number of components that sort of made us comfortable expanding into new markets last year and give us encouragement as we continue to expand. I think micro-merchandising is one piece, which really is a way of sort of adapting our assortments at a local level and trending those assortments more rapidly than we would've been able to before. So I think that's a very important tool in new markets. But I think some of the other investments we've made, I think -- the investments we've made in the merchant group over the last 5 years or so, which has benefitted the whole chain, should also benefit new markets in that the quality of the merchandise and the quality of the assortments has gone up. And I think the other aspect is the fact that we are carrying less inventory per store, which means that we're able to react much more quickly to trends that we see in an individual market. So I think there's a package of things that we've done in the last 2 years, which give us encouragement that we can be successful in our -- in the new markets.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Chain-wide as well, of course.
componenttext: Chain-wide as well, of course.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: You've been pretty quiet about the home business, and I was just curious if we can get a little bit of an update on the home business at Ross Stores and then how -- if it's also successful at dd's? And do you guys pack-away product in this space at all? I
componenttext: You've been pretty quiet about the home business, and I was just curious if we can get a little bit of an update on the home business at Ross Stores and then how -- if it's also successful at dd's? And do you guys pack-away product in this space at all? I was just curious.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Home business in both concepts, we're very pleased with. It's just not been in the top 2 performance of the company, in both companies. And we are very pleased with where we've -- the progress we've made. We also -- I would say we packaway some products,
componenttext: Home business in both concepts, we're very pleased with. It's just not been in the top 2 performance of the company, in both companies. And we are very pleased with where we've -- the progress we've made. We also -- I would say we packaway some products, but nothing in the -- nothing relatively large as we do in non-home businesses. But we use it selectively.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Excellent. Is it a similar business in dd's as it is in Ross?
componenttext: Excellent. Is it a similar business in dd's as it is in Ross?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a little different, okay. It's a little less gift-driven, and a little more utilitarian driven.
componenttext: It's a little different, okay. It's a little less gift-driven, and a little more utilitarian driven.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stacy Pak with Barclays Capital.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Omair filling in for Stacy. In Q4 thus far, we've seen a much better inventory control from apparel and retailers so far. What are you seeing in terms of inventory availability?
componenttext: This is Omair filling in for Stacy. In Q4 thus far, we've seen a much better inventory control from apparel and retailers so far. What are you seeing in terms of inventory availability?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Actually, we're seeing plenty of inventory availability. What the exact reason for that is? I know what I've been reading. I've been reading the same things you have, but there's been plenty of inventory in a fairly broad-based way.
componenttext: Actually, we're seeing plenty of inventory availability. What the exact reason for that is? I know what I've been reading. I've been reading the same things you have, but there's been plenty of inventory in a fairly broad-based way.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Klinefelter from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. One, with respect to the inventory reductions that you've executed in the stores, the significant reductions over last few years. I was just curious if you're now recognizing any opportunities or needs to reconsider store
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. One, with respect to the inventory reductions that you've executed in the stores, the significant reductions over last few years. I was just curious if you're now recognizing any opportunities or needs to reconsider store format, store fixturing? Any thoughts for kind of a net reduction in store prototype as you open new stores? And then one other thing, John, you commented on kind of the lack of shopping center development, kind of how that's playing into your cost of real estate. And I was curious if you could elaborate that on a little more? What are you seeing in the commercial development side? And what's happening net-net to your real estate costs?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take the question on the impact of inventories or less inventories on our stores. So we design our stores with flexible fixtures, and the flexibility enables us to expand and contract in any given category within a store. But as we brought down
componenttext: Yes, I'll take the question on the impact of inventories or less inventories on our stores. So we design our stores with flexible fixtures, and the flexibility enables us to expand and contract in any given category within a store. But as we brought down our inventories, we have a flexible model as well that enables us to open up smaller stores where needed. So based on the demographic information that we use, we'll either open a smaller-sized store to fit that need or a larger store. So we -- the model overall is very flexible, and it's worked well for us.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: But in general, we have, not in a dramatic way, we have shrunk our prototype a bit over the last couple years, knowing where we're going with our inventory reduction.
componenttext: But in general, we have, not in a dramatic way, we have shrunk our prototype a bit over the last couple years, knowing where we're going with our inventory reduction.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Jeff, on the second part of your question, when we take ownership and build out a store, the CapEx in that store is probably $1.5 million. If the landlord owns that, our fixturing, et cetera, costs about $0.5 million. That $1 million, you negotiate. Ob
componenttext: So Jeff, on the second part of your question, when we take ownership and build out a store, the CapEx in that store is probably $1.5 million. If the landlord owns that, our fixturing, et cetera, costs about $0.5 million. That $1 million, you negotiate. Obviously, you negotiate your rents down, so paid back over a period of time. And so as we see the credit markets get reestablished, development get reestablished, we'd want to switch back to more of the -- what we call a turnkey approach where the landlord is owning, but leasehold improvements would be our preference.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on the store prototype, Michael, is there a target prototype size, average size going forward that would deviate to some percentage from prior trends?
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow-up on the store prototype, Michael, is there a target prototype size, average size going forward that would deviate to some percentage from prior trends?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would say that the prototype size is smaller than what we've opened in the past. But we've always had a flexible model that's enabled us to open buildings that are larger than prototype. But I'd say most of them today tend to be -- tend to trend more to
componenttext: I would say that the prototype size is smaller than what we've opened in the past. But we've always had a flexible model that's enabled us to open buildings that are larger than prototype. But I'd say most of them today tend to be -- tend to trend more towards smaller than our average prototypes. So we're finding our -- the ability to merchandise these better than we have in the past. It provides us with increased availability when we're flexible and we're able to get different sizes. But one of the benefits of having less inventory is we don't need as big a building.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Montagna from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Montagna from Avondale Partners.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just kind of following along with the questions we were just talking about. Have you thought about moving the backlog forward to make the store look fuller? Because there's a lot of stores where I've been in where shelves are empty, walls are empty and po
componenttext: Just kind of following along with the questions we were just talking about. Have you thought about moving the backlog forward to make the store look fuller? Because there's a lot of stores where I've been in where shelves are empty, walls are empty and possibly try to improve the fullness look of the store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we spend a lot of time and resources ensuring that the customer experience is right by location. And some of the examples that you've given, we've moved -- we've added walls to make sure that we have a customer-friendly environment. And as we evol
componenttext: I think we spend a lot of time and resources ensuring that the customer experience is right by location. And some of the examples that you've given, we've moved -- we've added walls to make sure that we have a customer-friendly environment. And as we evolve our fixtures and as we evolve our merchandising standards and skills, it's focused on ensuring that the store looks right and is presented in an appropriate way for our customer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, then -- yes?
componenttext: Okay, then -- yes?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I would add that our customers seem to be responding favorably to having an environment that is easier to shop, and I understand that in some cases, we're showing a little more wall or a lot more wall and a lot more chrome. And the customers seemed to be
componenttext: I would add that our customers seem to be responding favorably to having an environment that is easier to shop, and I understand that in some cases, we're showing a little more wall or a lot more wall and a lot more chrome. And the customers seemed to be all favorably that, that is not a big issue for them if they're finding the right bargains.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just kind of along those lines, in terms of your in-store inventories. Can you talk about how fast the inventory is turning now versus how fast it was turning before you got on this inventory reduction initiative?
componenttext: Okay. And then just kind of along those lines, in terms of your in-store inventories. Can you talk about how fast the inventory is turning now versus how fast it was turning before you got on this inventory reduction initiative?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Mark. We're not public with the exact turn number. Clearly, inventories are down 40%. Sales were up, so it's turning significantly faster.
componenttext: Yes, sure, Mark. We're not public with the exact turn number. Clearly, inventories are down 40%. Sales were up, so it's turning significantly faster.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, in terms of expense leverage. Can you talk about what comp is needed this year to leverage SG&A expense and what comps would be needed for the buying and occupancy portion of gross margin?
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, in terms of expense leverage. Can you talk about what comp is needed this year to leverage SG&A expense and what comps would be needed for the buying and occupancy portion of gross margin?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we mentioned in the recorded comments, because we planned the year without the incentive, we're picking up some leverage from that. So this year, on the 1 to 2 comp, we're leveraging it a bit. Having said that, in a more comparable year-over-year
componenttext: Yes. As we mentioned in the recorded comments, because we planned the year without the incentive, we're picking up some leverage from that. So this year, on the 1 to 2 comp, we're leveraging it a bit. Having said that, in a more comparable year-over-year period, it takes about a 3 comp to leverage the expenses.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adrianne Shapira from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: A few questions. Just perhaps talk a little bit about if you can share with us some quarter-to-date comp trends in that the 9% you saw in February, we obviously see continued weather strength. March seems to be lapping an easier comparison. The 1% to 2% c
componenttext: A few questions. Just perhaps talk a little bit about if you can share with us some quarter-to-date comp trends in that the 9% you saw in February, we obviously see continued weather strength. March seems to be lapping an easier comparison. The 1% to 2% comp you've got planned for March, April, maybe if you could give us a little bit more color around that in terms of any updates on quarter-to-date, and also any sense of how you think about the Easter shift?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: So on -- Adrianne, our policy is really not to comment on mid-month sales. So we'll be out with that 1st Thursday of April.
componenttext: So on -- Adrianne, our policy is really not to comment on mid-month sales. So we'll be out with that 1st Thursday of April.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, and any help in terms of how to think about Easter? The 1% to 2%, it sounds like no shift in March, April, same?
componenttext: Okay, and any help in terms of how to think about Easter? The 1% to 2%, it sounds like no shift in March, April, same?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I can say this about it. That I think an earlier Easter is an advantage, okay? And that's as far as I think I can comment.
componenttext: Well, look, I can say this about it. That I think an earlier Easter is an advantage, okay? And that's as far as I think I can comment.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then question about when we think about -- you're hitting record EBIT levels this year. And obviously, next year, it sounds like we're going to set a new record. How should we think about dd's as that obviously has swung into improving profitabi
componenttext: Okay. And then question about when we think about -- you're hitting record EBIT levels this year. And obviously, next year, it sounds like we're going to set a new record. How should we think about dd's as that obviously has swung into improving profitability and that becomes less of a drag? How should we think about as that grows and that drag moderates? What potential help that could be to EBIT margins over time?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Adrianne, I'll take that. It's Michael O'Sullivan. As I've mentioned in an earlier -- in response to an earlier question, dd's has a pretty good 4-wall contribution level which tells us that as it scales up, it will become more profitable as a business. S
componenttext: Adrianne, I'll take that. It's Michael O'Sullivan. As I've mentioned in an earlier -- in response to an earlier question, dd's has a pretty good 4-wall contribution level which tells us that as it scales up, it will become more profitable as a business. So we think the long-term prospects for dd's are pretty good. I mean, I would caution you that right now, although dd's is profitable, it's less than 8% of our stores. So it's really not a material impact on our overall P&L. And it won't be for a few years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Any sense in terms of the differential, in terms of margin contribution, dd's versus Ross?
componenttext: Okay. Any sense in terms of the differential, in terms of margin contribution, dd's versus Ross?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: It so hard to answer that because dd's has less than 100 stores. Ross has more than 1,000. And that scale matters a lot. So it's hard to compare the 2. I think suffice it to say, obviously, we're very happy with Ross' EBIT margin. And our long-term models
componenttext: It so hard to answer that because dd's has less than 100 stores. Ross has more than 1,000. And that scale matters a lot. So it's hard to compare the 2. I think suffice it to say, obviously, we're very happy with Ross' EBIT margin. And our long-term models tell us that as dd's scales up, dd's will have an attractive profit margin.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my next question, you obviously have been capitalizing on whether it's a de-storing and the value focus out there. I'm just wondering, maybe if you could contextualize and shed some light in terms of the opportunities on the vendor r
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my next question, you obviously have been capitalizing on whether it's a de-storing and the value focus out there. I'm just wondering, maybe if you could contextualize and shed some light in terms of the opportunities on the vendor relationships, what categories you’re opening up? And without naming names, but how you're seeing the share shuffle that's going on, what that's doing in terms of opening doors to new vendors?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, this shuffling -- there's a lot of shuffling going on in the mid-Tier, and I certainly couldn't comment on any vendors, okay? But this kind of shuffling is usually good for us, okay. We're a constant. We're stable. We're focused. We have a large vol
componenttext: Well, this shuffling -- there's a lot of shuffling going on in the mid-Tier, and I certainly couldn't comment on any vendors, okay? But this kind of shuffling is usually good for us, okay. We're a constant. We're stable. We're focused. We have a large volume buying organization, seeing lots of vendors. So the shuffling you're talking about is usually a very good thing for us.

So I don't think it's quantifiable.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you talk little bit about the systems enhancements, the shrinkage reduction that's obviously led to margin improvement? What is next on the docket for systems or shrinkage that we should continue to see margin improvement? How do you think about it? A
componenttext: Can you talk little bit about the systems enhancements, the shrinkage reduction that's obviously led to margin improvement? What is next on the docket for systems or shrinkage that we should continue to see margin improvement? How do you think about it? And then also, as you think about the buyers, and we've always heard about adding to the buying team, where are you on the people side and what should be added? Any new categories we should be watching for?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dana, let me take the first part of your question and split it into 2. I'll address the systems issue, and then separately, we'll talk about shrink. So on systems, we're -- I guess, the way we think about it is there are 3 buckets to sort of systems inves
componenttext: Dana, let me take the first part of your question and split it into 2. I'll address the systems issue, and then separately, we'll talk about shrink. So on systems, we're -- I guess, the way we think about it is there are 3 buckets to sort of systems investment. There is firstly, sort of continually upgrading and improving our systems or improving things like information security and merchandise and operational reporting, a bunch of things like that, that we do on a continual basis. Secondly, there’s systems investments that we make to sort of improve what I would call operational efficiency within our stores or within our IPCs. And then certainly, there's a bucket of what I'd call strategic investments, things like micro-merchandising. And we continue to look for those kind of sort of strategic investments, ways that IT systems investment can help the overall business. And we have some things in the pipeline, nothing on the scale of micro-merchandising at this point, but things that we're looking at. So that's kind of how I'd sum up the systems side of things.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll take the shortage question. As we said earlier, we're on our third year of -- third consecutive year of record lows in shortage. With that said, we continue to make targeted strategic investments designed to control our current levels of shortage. Bu
componenttext: I'll take the shortage question. As we said earlier, we're on our third year of -- third consecutive year of record lows in shortage. With that said, we continue to make targeted strategic investments designed to control our current levels of shortage. But with that, we're hopeful to do better.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012

componenttext: On the buying side, in -- from '11, -- in '11, I think we grew our merchant organization slightly over 10%. And I would think we'll probably -- we'll be growing the organization about the same amount in fiscal '12. There are new categories that we are putting into our store, but in this environment, I just wouldn't be comfortable discussing it.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Last year, at this point, we were trying to speculate about the impact of higher input costs and the impact that may have on your business. I wonder if you could share your thoughts as we look out to the potential benefit of lower sourcing costs in the se
componenttext: Last year, at this point, we were trying to speculate about the impact of higher input costs and the impact that may have on your business. I wonder if you could share your thoughts as we look out to the potential benefit of lower sourcing costs in the second half and what, if any, impact that could have on your profitability.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Certainly, what happened last year in import cost and what was not -- was something we all have to get used to and the customer had to get used to a bit. In some cases, they did; in some cases, they didn't. As we move towards fall, there are some re
componenttext: Okay. Certainly, what happened last year in import cost and what was not -- was something we all have to get used to and the customer had to get used to a bit. In some cases, they did; in some cases, they didn't. As we move towards fall, there are some reductions going on as cotton prices have come down significantly. And I think the potential benefit for an off-price retailer is as prices come down, I would expect that certain places in the market will invest more in product. If they do that and business is not strong in mainstream, there'll be opportunities for us. And that's how I think -- where I see the potential benefit for us.

componenttext: Just another question. I know this was already asked, but maybe I'll ask it in a different way. On the March, April same store sales guidance, the up 1% to 2% in both months just -- I mean, you look back over the years and you typically do see a pretty major difference in your March same store sales and your April same store sales. For like last year, March was down 1%, April was up 10%. That big swing is pretty clear over the years. So I'm just wondering why -- and Easter this year is 2 weeks earlier. And -- so I'm wondering why this year would look different, why we wouldn't see some kind of a fairly significant swing those months?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Mar 15, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Easter is moving what, a week or 2? I mean, it's 2 weeks. It's probably -- you had some minimal move compared to when it moved in 2010, it was more significant. So from our perspective, it's not going to be that significant kind of inter-month. Ha
componenttext: I think Easter is moving what, a week or 2? I mean, it's 2 weeks. It's probably -- you had some minimal move compared to when it moved in 2010, it was more significant. So from our perspective, it's not going to be that significant kind of inter-month. Having said that, I'll reiterate again, our policy is not to comment on sales mid-month, but we do want to make sure that we are prepared to get through the Easter season, which I think we'll do fine. And Easter, obviously, this year is still in fiscal April, then switching to March, obviously.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]Before we get started, on behalf
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2011 Form 10-K, and Fiscal 2012 Form 8-Ks on file with the SEC.
Now I would like to turn the call over to Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Paul, Group Senior Vice President and Ch
componenttext:
Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Paul, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director, Investor Relations. 
We will begin with a brief review of our first quarter performance, followed by our outlook for the second quarter and fiscal year. We will conclude with some comments about our longer-term growth aspects. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have.
We are pleased with our much better than expected financial results in the first quarter. Our robust sales and earnings were driven mainly by our ongoing ability to deliver a wide array of fresh and exciting namebrand to the today's value focused consumers. In addition, we believe that favorable weather across many of our markets also contributed to our above-planned performance. Our ability to operate our business with lower in-store inventories and strictly controlled expenses also continued to enhance both sales and profit margins.
Earnings per share for the 13 weeks ended April 28, 2012, were $0.93, up from a split-adjusted $0.74 in the prior year. These results represent a 26% increase on top of a 28% gain in the same period last year. Net earnings for the 2012 first quarter were 21% from $208.6 million. Sales rose 14% to $2,357,000,000 , with comparable store sales up 9% on top of 3% growth in the first quarter of 2011. Merchandise and geographic trends were per based, Juniors and Accessories were the best-performing categories while Florida remained the top region. 
Earnings before interest and taxes grew to a record 14.4% of sales, up about 70 basis points on top of an exceptional 160-basis point increase in the prior year. Our improved profit margin versus last year was driven primarily by leverage on expenses from the strong gains in same-store sales and higher merchandise gross margin. John will provide some additional color on these operating margin trends in a few minutes.
As we entered the first quarter, total consolidated inventories declined about 3% compared to the prior year, mainly due to lower levels that were about 45% of total inventories, down from 48% at this time last year. More importantly, average in-store inventories declined about 9%. For the balance of the year, we are targeting a mid- single-digit percentage decrease in selling store inventories compared to 2011. 
Like Ross, dd's is also benefiting from our ability to flow a larger percentage of fresh products to our stores by operating on lower inventory levels. Dd's above-planned sales and margin in the first quarter reflect that its this merchandise offerings continue to resonate well with its value-focused customers.
Our store expansion program is on track with a total of about 80 locations scheduled to open during 2012 comprised of 60 Ross and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS. 
Now John will provide further color on our first quarter results and details on our second quarter 2012 guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 9% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions combined with a low-single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by ab
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 9% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions combined with a low-single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by about 70 basis points in the quarter to 14.4%. Leverage on the robust 9% comparable store sales gain drove a 55-basis point reduction in selling, general and administrative expenses, while cost of goods sold as a percent of sales was 15 basis points lower than the prior year. Merchandise margin grew by 35 basis points, including 10 basis points from a lower shrink accrual while occupancy expenses levered by about 20 basis points. These favorable trends more than offset higher distribution costs of 20 basis points related to pathway timing and 10-basis point increases each in freight and buying cost. The 55 basis points of improved SG&A was driven mainly by lower store expenses as a percent of sales. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 2 million shares for a total purchase price of $111 million. We remain on track to buy back a total of $450 million in common stock during fiscal 2012 to complete the 2-year $900 million program authorized in early 2011. 
Let's turn now to our second quarter guidance. For the 13 weeks ending July 28, 2012, we now are targeting in-store sales to increase 3% to 4% on top of a 5% gain in the prior year. Second quarter 2012 earnings per share are forecast to be in the range of $0.72 to $0.75. This represents projected EPS growth of 13% to 17% on top of a 20% increase in the prior --  in the second quarter of 2011. Our second quarter 2012 EPS targets are based on the following assumptions: Total sales are expected to grow about 8% to 9%, driven by a combination of new store growth and as I just mentioned same-store sales that are forecast to be up 3% to 4%. We plan to open about 20 net new stores during the period, including 21 Ross Dress for Less and 7 dd's DISCOUNTS. Comparable store sales are forecast to increase 4% to 5% in May, 3% to 4% in June and 2% to 3% in July. 
Last year, same-store sales rose 4%, 5% and 7% in May, June and July, respectively.
We are targeting operating margin of 11.9% to 12.1% for the 2012 second quarter, up 2o to 40 basis points from 11.7% in last year's second quarter. An increase in merchandise gross margin combined with leverage on selling, general and administrative costs is projected to drive the operating margin improvement. Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2 million, and our tax rate is expected to be above 39%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about $224 million. Now I'll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. As noted in today's press release, we are raising our 2012 guidance with earnings per share for the 53 weeks ending February 7, 2013 now forecast to be in the range of $3.26 to $3.37. This compares to our prior guidance of $3.12 to $3.27
componenttext:
Thank you, John. As noted in today's press release, we are raising our 2012 guidance with earnings per share for the 53 weeks ending February 7, 2013 now forecast to be in the range of $3.26 to $3.37. This compares to our prior guidance of $3.12 to $3.27 and earnings per share of $2.86 in fiscal 2011. The 53rd week in 2012 is projected to add about $0.08 to $0.09 to earnings per share. We are confident in our ability to meet these targets for a couple of reasons. First, we remain well positioned in the off price space in the current retail environment. Equally important is our strong belief that we can continue to diligently execute the most critical strategic initiatives of our business. These include ongoing investments in our merchandise organization, further reductions to inventories in our stores and our continuing efforts to fine-tune and implement systems and processes that strengthen our ability to get the right merchandise to the right store at the right time. 
In addition, we are pleased to report that our accelerated growth into new markets for Ross Dress for Less remains on plan. We initially ended Illinois last October with 12 stores in the greater Chicago area, followed by openings in Arkansas and Missouri. During the balance of 2012, we expect to add more locations in these 3 states while also entering Canada, Kentucky and Indiana for the first time.
We also are now even more bullish about our total expansion prospects over the longer term. As noted in today's press release, we've increased our long-term projected store potential to 2,500 locations in the United States. Our current in-depth research and proven ability to cluster stores closer together indicate that we can more fully saturate existing and new markets. As a result, we currently believe that Ross Dress for Less can grow to approximately 2,000 locations across the country, up from our prior target of 1,500. We also continue to project that dd's DISCOUNTS can become a chain of about 500 stores. Combined, this means we have the ability over time to more than double the size of our company domestically, an exciting prospect. At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012

componenttextpreview: Michael, I'm wondering what analysis, if you could share with us, you performed to assess the real potential of Ross Stores? And obviously we can look at the map and the geographical exposure and see there's so much potential here in the United States, bu
componenttext: Michael, I'm wondering what analysis, if you could share with us, you performed to assess the real potential of Ross Stores? And obviously we can look at the map and the geographical exposure and see there's so much potential here in the United States, but maybe you could just given us a bit of the analysis behind how you determine the long-term potential for your store base and what was it that in particular drove the update to guidance today?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan, I'm going to answer that question. There are really 2 sets of things that we did. The first was we looked at the market that we currently operate in, in terms of number of stores per population. And we look at quarter to
componenttext: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan, I'm going to answer that question. There are really 2 sets of things that we did. The first was we looked at the market that we currently operate in, in terms of number of stores per population. And we look at quarter to graphics in terms of in our target customers and how many of our target customers are within each market. And then we find to make an assessment about the real estate opportunities would be in each market. And then we built it up so bottom-up market by market to come up with estimate, which as Michael described going from 1,500 stores to 2,000. The other point I would make is that we also we've taken a look at the success that we've had over the last several years in some of our newer markets, Southeast and the Atlantic that, that give us confidence in terms of some of the we used to come up with these investments.

componenttextpreview: Paul, as Michael mentioned, we opened 14 stores in October in new markets. 12 of those were in Chicago and then we opened another 4 new market I think this past March. And so far, I mean, I would caution you still pretty early, I mean the stores have been
componenttext: Paul, as Michael mentioned, we opened 14 stores in October in new markets. 12 of those were in Chicago and then we opened another 4 new market I think this past March. And so far, I mean, I would caution you still pretty early, I mean the stores have been opened 6 or 7 months, but so far we're pretty happy with how we opening have gone. And I'm missing not just in terms of sales, but also customer resets that we've done and feedback that we've had from the customers. So we're pretty happy with how those stores have gone so far. I think the more important point is everything we see in terms of what we that market to reinforce Ross looking successful in those new markets long-term. So we're feeling pretty good. That expect your question, we learned anything or seen anything in terms of where the patents or assortments issues. Nothing out of the ordinary. I think we've planned the market pretty well. We feel pretty happy about our plans. Tweaks we're going to make to the assortments but nothing different than what we would do with most of the new stores. But we're pretty happy with happening and going.

componenttext: It's hard to say how that really trend for the year opportunities. We're seeing buying opportunities that are actually improving significantly as we move to the season. So I think and some of the product also that might have gone to packaway has slowed directly to our stores now. So packaway, keep in mind, some of the best product that we can buy and we expect based on market conditions that we're seeing at certain levels of retailing that there's going to be a sizable amount of product that were seeing both will up at this point.

componenttext: Michael, I just had a question on some of the product trends, I mean Juniors and Accessories standing out as top-performing. Just curious given your packaway business model how you are dealing with that kind of quickly uptrending product category?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Color is the key fashion component this season and in our business, when we really want to get current and color, something like that, that really is done in more upfront product rather than packaway, last year. And in all likelihood, we probably would no
componenttext: Color is the key fashion component this season and in our business, when we really want to get current and color, something like that, that really is done in more upfront product rather than packaway, last year. And in all likelihood, we probably would not be buying into that for packaway for 2 reasons. One, it will be less available and two, it will be more risky that successful colors today aren't necessarily going to be the right ones for the spring when you have fashion shift that we go into. So the color is driving the business in the areas you said and beyond in the store.

componenttext: To a degree, to a degree. Those -- so where we've seen the fashion trends early and up and we're able to buy into it, the answer is obviously yes, and there are certain markets where we  didn't. Remember, the market is on color there's a certain level of clothes out that are available and probably not enough for everyone's pipeline. So we think we will have an adequate level. It's probably the best way to answer it.

componenttext: I wanted to ask about what's impressive is your ability to run your stores and compounds with the lower inventory levels. Can you talk about what kind of changes you've made so far in your supply chain and distribution. Is there further investments you need to make to continue with the strategy?

componenttextpreview: Average.
componenttext: Average.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ever, it's Michael O'Sullivan. In terms of investments, I think we've mentioned before that over the next few years, we expect to open up a couple of major additional distribution centers to keep pace with that growth. So that's the forward-looking piece.
componenttext: Ever, it's Michael O'Sullivan. In terms of investments, I think we've mentioned before that over the next few years, we expect to open up a couple of major additional distribution centers to keep pace with that growth. So that's the forward-looking piece. In terms of changes we've made over the last 5 to 6 years, we made a number of adjustments to how we process and how we flow those goods from the DCs to the stores to trying to speed up that process to get that in transit as low as possible. I think that certainly contributed to our ability to carry that inventory to the stores.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012

componenttext: I would also add that the investment in dollars and processes and people that we put in place and planning in a more localized level also has helped to make our ability to turn our merchandise faster and have the right product at the right store at the right time possible.

componenttext: So Laura, I mean right now there's 2 pieces. So in terms of the store potential that Michael referenced, the 1,500 stores and 2,000 stores, obviously that's our long-term potential. And we look at that periodically. And based upon a number of factors in the few years we  felt it was appropriate to raise that number. componenttext: Sure. So David, dd's has been fairly profitable for the last couple of years, it's been accretive to our earnings. And dd's in 2011 saw a pretty significant increase in profitability. Dd's similar approach to what for taking across in terms of lowering inventory levels and using that to drive margins and to drive sales. So given that profitability, we see that continuing to Q1, and we expect dd's contribution to continue to improve in 2012.

componenttext: So we had a 20-basis point exposure in the first quarter based on the packaway timing. To answer your question, as  we've looked at our stores that are near other midtier stores they are doing very well. So we will also look at our stores are are near and are doing very well too. So you talk it's hard for us to give you these an answer in terms of quantifying where we're getting our share gains. Suffice to say that where the 9% comp they're coming from somewhere.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in the new store targets you're talking about that some of the stores are going to be put closer together. How are you modeling or size of stores, sales productivity of stores, how should we think about the breakeven cost open stores in this
componenttext: You mentioned in the new store targets you're talking about that some of the stores are going to be put closer together. How are you modeling or size of stores, sales productivity of stores, how should we think about the breakeven cost open stores in this new prototype for both concepts?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dana, in terms of getting to that 2,000 store potential, we actually haven't made an assumption that stores will necessarily be. What we've done is we've looked at places where we don't have stores or places where we have opportunity to stores. And based
componenttext: Dana, in terms of getting to that 2,000 store potential, we actually haven't made an assumption that stores will necessarily be. What we've done is we've looked at places where we don't have stores or places where we have opportunity to stores. And based upon what we already know in terms of how many Ross stores market can support and based on what we already know about store volumes and the possibility of those stores, that's how we built up the 2,000. We haven't stretched 2,000 and said can we load even more stores than we currently operate in the markets or can we achieve sales productivity levels that we don't currently achieve. We really model it on what we've already achieved in terms of individual store performance. And as I said, we looked at places where we don't have stores or places where we know we have lots of opportunities for additional stores.

componenttext: Well, we have approximately 1,100 stores right now. Given that our pace of new store growth is around 70 stores a year, to get to 2,000, it's a long way off before we get that potential.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behal
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Ross Stores First Quarter 2012 Earnings Release Conference Call. The call will begin with prepared comments by management followed by a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectation about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2011 Form 10-K and fiscal 2012 Form 8-Ks on file with the SEC.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Michael Balmuth, Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Ch
componenttext:
Good morning. Joining me on our call today are Norman Ferber, Chairman of the Board; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Bobbi Chaville, Senior Director, Investor Relations. 
We will begin with a brief review of our first quarter performance, followed by our outlook for the second quarter and fiscal year. We'll conclude with some comments about our longer-term growth prospects. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have.
We are pleased with our much better-than-expected financial results in the first quarter. Our robust sales and earnings were driven mainly by our ongoing ability to deliver a wide array of fresh and exciting name-brand bargains to today's value-focused consumers. In addition, we believe that favorable weather across many of our markets also contributed to our above-planned performance. Our ability to operate our business with lower in-store inventories and strictly controlled expenses also continued to enhance both sales and profit margins.
Earnings per share for the 13 weeks ended April 28, 2012, were $0.93, up from a split-adjusted $0.74 in the prior year. These results represent a 26% increase on top of a 28% gain in the same period last year. Net earnings for the 2012 first quarter were up 21% to $208.6 million. Sales rose 14% to $2,357,000,000 , with comparable store sales up 9% on top of 3% growth in the first quarter of 2011. Merchandise and geographic trends were broad-based. Juniors and Accessories were the best-performing categories, while Florida remained the top region. 
Earnings before interest and taxes grew to a record 14.4% of sales, up about 70 basis points on top of an exceptional 160-basis point increase in the prior year. Our improved profit margin versus last year was driven primarily by leverage on expenses from the strong gains in same-store sales and higher merchandise gross margin. John will provide some additional color on these operating margin trends in a few minutes.
As we entered the first quarter, total consolidated inventories declined about 3% compared to the prior year, mainly due to lower packaway levels that were about 45% of total inventories, down from 48% at this time last year. More importantly, average in-store inventories declined about 9%. For the balance of the year, we are targeting a mid- single-digit percentage decrease in selling store inventories compared to 2011. 
Like Ross, dd's is also benefiting from our ability to flow a larger percentage of fresh products to our stores by operating on lower inventory levels. dd's above-planned sales and margin in the first quarter reflect that its merchandise offerings continue to resonate well with its value-focused customers. Our store expansion program is on track, with a total of about 80 locations scheduled to open during 2012, comprised of 60 Ross and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS. 
Now John will provide further color on our first quarter results and details on our second quarter 2012 guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. Our 9% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions, combined with the low-single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. Our 9% comparable store sales gain in the first quarter was driven by mid-single-digit growth in the number of transactions, combined with the low-single-digit increase in the size of the average basket. Again, operating margin grew by about 70 basis points in the quarter to 14.4%. Leverage on the robust 9% comparable store sales gain drove a 55 basis point reduction in selling, general and administrative expenses, while cost of goods sold as a percent of sales was 15 basis points lower than the prior year. 
Merchandise margin grew by 35 basis points, including 10 basis points from a lower shrink accrual, while occupancy expenses levered by about 20 basis points. These favorable trends more than offset higher distribution costs of 20 basis points related to packaway timing and 10-basis point increases each in freight and buying cost. The 55 basis points of improved SG&A was driven mainly by lower store expenses as a percent of sales. 
During the first quarter, we repurchased 2 million shares for a total purchase price of $111 million. We remain on track to buy back a total of $450 million in common stock during fiscal 2012 to complete the 2-year $900 million program authorized in early 2011. 
Let's turn now to our second quarter guidance. For the 13 weeks ending July 28, 2012, we now are targeting in-store sales to increase 3% to 4% on top of a 5% gain in the prior year. Second quarter 2012 earnings per share are forecast to be in the range of $0.72 to $0.75. This represents projected EPS growth of 13% to 17% on top of a 20% increase in the prior --  in the second quarter of 2011. 
Our second quarter 2012 EPS targets are based on the following assumptions. Total sales are expected to grow about 8% to 9%, driven by a combination of new store growth and as I just mentioned, same-store sales that are forecast to be up 3% to 4%. We plan to open about 28 net new stores during the period, including 21 Ross Dress for Less and 7 dd's DISCOUNTS. Comparable store sales are forecast to increase 4% to 5% in May, 3% to 4% in June and 2% to 3% in July. Last year, same-store sales rose 4%, 5% and 7% in May, June and July, respectively. 
We are targeting operating margin of 11.9% to 12.1% for the 2012 second quarter, up 20 to 40 basis points from 11.7% in last year's second quarter. An increase in merchandise gross margin, combined with the leverage on selling, general and administrative cost, is projected to drive the operating margin improvement. Net interest expense is planned to be approximately $2 million, and our tax rate is expected to be above 39%. We also estimate weighted average diluted shares outstanding of about 224 million. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Michael.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. As noted in today's press release, we are raising our 2012 guidance, with earnings per share for the 53 weeks ending February 7, 2013, now forecast to be in the range of $3.26 to $3.37. This compares to our prior guidance of $3.12 to $3.2
componenttext:
Thank you, John. As noted in today's press release, we are raising our 2012 guidance, with earnings per share for the 53 weeks ending February 7, 2013, now forecast to be in the range of $3.26 to $3.37. This compares to our prior guidance of $3.12 to $3.27 and earnings per share of $2.86 in fiscal 2011. The 53rd week in 2012 is projected to add about $0.08 to $0.09 to earnings per share. 
We are confident in our ability to meet these targets for a couple of reasons. First, we remain well positioned in the off-price space in the current retail environment. Equally important is our strong belief that we can continue to diligently execute the most critical strategic initiatives of our business. These include ongoing investments in our merchandise organization, further reductions to inventories in our stores and our continuing efforts to fine-tune and implement systems and processes that strengthen our ability to get the right merchandise to the right store at the right time. 
In addition, we are pleased to report that our accelerated growth into new markets for Ross Dress for Less remains on plan. We initially entered Illinois last October with 12 stores in the greater Chicago area, followed by openings in Arkansas and Missouri. During the balance of 2012, we expect to add more locations in these 3 states while also entering Kansas, Kentucky and Indiana for the first time.
We also are now even more bullish about our total expansion prospects over the longer term. As noted in today's press release, we have increased our long-term projected store potential to 2,500 locations in the United States. Our current in-depth research and proven ability to cluster stores closer together indicate that we can more fully saturate existing and new markets. As a result, we currently believe that Ross Dress for Less can grow to approximately 2,000 locations across the country, up from our prior target of 1,500. We also continue to project that dd's DISCOUNTS can become a chain of about 500 stores. Combined, this means we have the ability, over time, to more than double the size of our company domestically, an exciting prospect. 
At this point, we would like to open up the call and respond to any questions you may have.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'm wondering what analysis, if you could share with us, you performed to assess the real potential of Ross Stores? And obviously, we can look at the map and the geographical exposure and see there's so much more potential here in the United Stat
componenttext: Michael, I'm wondering what analysis, if you could share with us, you performed to assess the real potential of Ross Stores? And obviously, we can look at the map and the geographical exposure and see there's so much more potential here in the United States. But maybe you could just share with us a bit of the analysis behind how you determine the long-term potential for your store base and what was it that in particular drove the update to guidance today. That would be great.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I'll answer that question. There are really 2 sets of things that we did. The first was we looked at the market that we currently operate in, in terms of number of stores per population, and we looked at broader demograp
componenttext: Kimberly, it's Michael O'Sullivan. I'll answer that question. There are really 2 sets of things that we did. The first was we looked at the market that we currently operate in, in terms of number of stores per population, and we looked at broader demographics in terms of in our target customer and how many of our target customer are within each market. And then, we tried to make an assessment of what the real estate opportunities would be in each market. And then, we built it up, so bottom-up market by market to come up with sort of big estimate, which, as Michael described, going from 1,500 stores to 2,000. The other point I would make though is we also -- we've taken a look at the success that we've had over the last several years in some of our newer markets, the Southeast and the mid-Atlantic that, again, that gave us confidence in terms of some of the deputy estimates that we've used to come up with the assessment.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012

componenttextpreview: Just wondering when you look at the Chicago market and the 12 stores that you opened in Illinois, how many are hitting plan versus above plan. And I guess, I'm just wondering given that, that market tends to be a little bit more weather-sensitive than som
componenttext: Just wondering when you look at the Chicago market and the 12 stores that you opened in Illinois, how many are hitting plan versus above plan. And I guess, I'm just wondering given that, that market tends to be a little bit more weather-sensitive than some of your other regions, how do you feel you guys did in terms of getting that right product in those stores at the right time.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Paul, as Michael mentioned, we opened 14 stores in October in new markets. 12 of those were in Chicago, and then we opened another 4 in new markets this past March. And so far, I mean, I would caution you, it's still pretty early. I mean, those stores
componenttext: So Paul, as Michael mentioned, we opened 14 stores in October in new markets. 12 of those were in Chicago, and then we opened another 4 in new markets this past March. And so far, I mean, I would caution you, it's still pretty early. I mean, those stores have been opened 6 or 7 months. But so far we're pretty happy with how the openings have gone. And I'm basing that not just in terms of sales, but also quality customer research that we've done and feedback that we've had from the customers. So we're pretty happy with how those stores have gone so far. I think the more important point is everything we see in terms of what we've learned in that market still reinforces, for us, that we're going to successful in those new markets long term. So we're feeling pretty good. The final aspect of your question, have we learned anything or seen anything in terms of were there patterns or assortment issues, nothing out of the ordinary. I think we've planned the market pretty well. We feel pretty happy about our plans. Yes, there are some tweaks we're going to make to the assortments, but nothing different than what we would do with most new stores. But I think we're pretty happy with how things are openings are going.

componenttext: So packaway inventories declined on a year-over-year basis as a percentage of total inventory and in dollars. So can you just help us think about the implications of that? Are you seeing less compelling product in the marketplace than you did versus last year? Does it have to do with changes in product cost? And then, how do you expect the packaway inventories to trend as we go through the year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say how they'll really trend through the year just based on opportunities. We're seeing buying opportunities that are actually improving significantly as we move through the season. Part of the reason our packaway level is a little below last
componenttext: It's hard to say how they'll really trend through the year just based on opportunities. We're seeing buying opportunities that are actually improving significantly as we move through the season. Part of the reason our packaway level is a little below last year is we're, so far, exceeding our sales plans that we just have to hold some of that forward into our stores. So I think and some of the product also that might have went to packaway has flowed directly to our stores now. So packaway, keep in mind is some of the best product that we can buy and is closed out. And we expect, based on market conditions that we're seeing at certain levels of retailing, that there's going to be a sizable amount of product than were seeing than what's open at this point.

componenttextpreview: Michael, I just had a question on some of the product trends. I mean, Juniors and Accessories standing out as top-performing, I think that's great and in some cases, in contrast to some of the other kind of moderate department stores' own trend. Just curi
componenttext: Michael, I just had a question on some of the product trends. I mean, Juniors and Accessories standing out as top-performing, I think that's great and in some cases, in contrast to some of the other kind of moderate department stores' own trend. Just curious if that's -- any other context around it or any other detail around it? Tops versus bottoms, are you seeing it broad-based across those categories? And specifically on color, I think we're all hearing about color driving business right now in fashion and some others are kind of caught behind and chasing the color product. Just curious given your packaway business model, how you're dealing with that kind of quickly up-trending product category.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, color is the key fashion component this season. And in our business, when we really want to get current color, something like that, that really is done in more upfront product rather than packaway. It was the deal last year. And in all likelih
componenttext: Okay. Well, color is the key fashion component this season. And in our business, when we really want to get current color, something like that, that really is done in more upfront product rather than packaway. It was the deal last year. And in all likelihood, we probably would not be buying into that for packaway for 2 reasons: one, it will be less available; and two, it would be more risky. Of course, the successful colors today aren't necessarily going to be the right ones for next spring when you have the fashion shift that we're going through. So the color is driving the business in the areas you said and beyond in the store.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, in terms of just keeping up with that and potentially chasing it into -- all the way through the summer, eventually to the fall, that's something that you feel very comfortable you can keep up with, with upfront buys in your market?
componenttext: Okay. And then, in terms of just keeping up with that and potentially chasing it into -- all the way through the summer, eventually to the fall, that's something that you feel very comfortable you can keep up with, with upfront buys in your market?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, May 17, 2012
componenttextpreview: To a degree, to a degree, okay? Those -- so where we've seen the fashion trends early and up and we're able to buy into it, the answer is obviously yes, and there are certain pockets where we  didn't. Remember, the market is -- on color, there's a certain
componenttext: To a degree, to a degree, okay? Those -- so where we've seen the fashion trends early and up and we're able to buy into it, the answer is obviously yes, and there are certain pockets where we  didn't. Remember, the market is -- on color, there's a certain level of clothes out that are available, and it's probably not enough to fill everyone's pipeline. So we think we'll have an adequate level, okay? It's probably the best way to answer it.
